title: I got banned for saying stuff
body:
I try to be a nice league player. I'm not toxic. But today when I played with my friends in a premade team, a friend told me to say neck yourself 3 times because we were playing around and he was pretending to be my leader. I said neck yourself twice and my other friends told me that that would get me banned. I stopped and said "i'm jk" and "pls" There's no reason for me to be mad at my team. After the match he reported me. I got a 14 day ban immediately. I've never been chat restricted or banned. Like I get it that you guys are trying to crack down on toxic teammates, but in my case I was banned for saying something that I was told to say to my 5 man team that isn't directed towards anyone. I didn't know that it was that bad when I was saying it. Can someone review my situation and help me out.

Update, I went and asked the four other people I played with, they didn't report me. No one reported me on my team and I said it in team chat

"Neck Yourself" is reference to commit suicide by hanging one self. Or at least around where I live it is.
"Go neck yourself" is considered the same as "kill yourself."
Because Riot never takes things into context. Wonderful 0 tolerance systems.

That's kind of the result of prioritizing fighting toxicity. The rare exception is easily fixed via support ticket, as we've seen many times.

I'm curious how you think the system could be improved.

First, get rid of 0 tolerance policy. Context is key. Riot has long held the stance of "context is unimportant." That's simply not true. Related to that:

Prioritize the causes of toxicity and not the symptoms. 

Trolling/Inting, and punishing the incendiary player rather than the retaliator

Stop punishing people just for saying things without taking them into context. There's no such thing as a "toxic person." Everyone can just as often be toxic as they can be nice. 

Toxicity always seems to start from one person and then grow out of control. What Riot suggests you to do right now is to just mute and keep playing. That doesn't solve the problem, that just bottles it up. 

There won't be a system that will realistically deal with "game hostage" scenarios where you're forced to play with a incendiary player/troll for 15+ minutes. 

What the system can do is take context into account and avoid punishing players who are merely getting tilted or angry at the incendiary player/troll. This cannot, unfortunately be done with an automated system, so it will never be implemented.

The only way for context to be taken into account is with humans, and that system will always be slower than automation.



Incendiary players, too, are toxic because of some outside factor angering/tilting them. The difference between them and retaliators is that retaliators will tend to become toxic in response to incendiary players, while incendiary players will become toxic due to incendiary players AND gameplay factors.

At the end of the day, "context is key" is an opinion, not a fact, and it's an opinion that is actually contradicted by the majority of the player base. 

Similarly, "toxicity stems from trolling" is an opinion unsupported by any data. People are toxic for a wide variety of reasons, many of which stem from the privileged belief that League culture should permit it. If you think about it, by telling people they aren't responsible for their behavior - "they were triggered by trolling" - you're actually _enabling_ toxicity.

As to your larger response, you've basically thrown your hands in the air and said that nothing works. By your lights, automated systems fail because they don't address what you consider to be the sole cause of toxicity and there simply isn't enough manpower to have humans reviewing all the reports in anything approaching a timely fashion.

I guess my question as to how you would improve the system remains unanswered.

>At the end of the day, "context is key" is an opinion, not a fact, and it's an opinion that is actually contradicted by the majority of the player base.

The very interpretation of "toxicity" and "toxic" is opinion and not fact. To try and treat it as such is stupid.

Also, it's my opinion. I'm not speaking to represent everyone.

>Similarly, "toxicity stems from trolling" is an opinion unsupported by any data. 

Because there's no data to be gathered. Any "official" data we have is from Riot, and they don't keep track of it. Because they can't. As mentioned previously there's no automated way to deal with context.

> If you think about it, by telling people they aren't responsible for their behavior - "they were triggered by trolling" - you're actually enabling toxicity.

I am, because that toxicity is fully justifiable. Always try to go for the source, and not the symptoms. Those people should try to restrain themselves from going over-the-top, but their anger and "toxicity" is justified. Riot disagrees with this.


>As to your larger response, you've basically thrown your hands in the air and said that nothing works. By your lights, automated systems fail because they don't address what you consider to be the sole cause of toxicity and there simply isn't enough manpower to have humans reviewing all the reports in anything approaching a timely fashion.

>I guess my question as to how you would improve the system remains unanswered.

Correct. The system is inherently flawed.

You aren't ever going to have a good, automated system that can judge human interaction.

>I am, because that toxicity is fully justifiable.

Again, that's an opinion you're allowed to have, but it's not compatible with either Riot's policies or with what the community wants.

You keep trying to argue that we should permit more behavior because of this abstract idea you have. You may wish to consider that you're looking at this from an entirely irrelevant perspective. This is Riot's space, which means they have the authority - in every sense - to regulate it as they see fit. That they do so based on what the community wants is to their credit - and good business practice, to boot.

> Correct. The system is inherently flawed.
> 
> You aren't ever going to have a good, automated system that can judge human interaction.

Well, they already have a "good" system, seeing as how most people are happy with it, when they think about it at all. You're missing how the system is _effective_ when you focus on what you perceive as an irreparable failing. Behavior that drives away business - which is an objective definition of "toxic", by the way - is unwelcome regardless of its source and is _never_ subject to justification.

At no point can anyone legitimately say "I called him a slew of racial and homophobic slurs because he was feeding". It's just not possible.

> Again, that's an opinion you're allowed to have, but it's not compatible with either Riot's policies or with what the community wants.

And that's their opinion. I disagree with them, they disagree with me. 

>You keep trying to argue that we should permit more behavior because of this abstract idea you have. You may wish to consider that you're looking at this from an entirely irrelevant perspective. This is Riot's space, which means they have the authority - in every sense - to regulate it as they see fit. That they do so based on what the community wants is to their credit - and good business practice, to boot.

And that's why I've addressed Riot many times. I think Riot's stance is wrong. Riot are the ones enforcing this system from the Lyte days. I highly doubt the community is on board with it now. In the beginning (I mean really old, Tribunal days) the community could've been onboard, but ever since Lyte and co. took an active role by revamping the toxicity system, I really doubt they asked the community for input on every little thing.

It's probably something more like:
Community: "there's too much toxicity in the game"
Riot: "Ok"

>Well, they already have a "good" system, seeing as how most people are happy with it, when they think about it at all.

Going to have to ask for stats on this one.

>You're missing how the system is effective when you focus on what you perceive as an irreparable failing. Behavior that drives away business - which is an objective definition of "toxic", by the way - is unwelcome regardless of its source and is never subject to justification.

That is not the objective definition of toxic. That's a general business strategy. 

Toxicity is a behavior that originates from people and varies case by case. It is something that everyone has, and is justifiable.

>At no point can anyone legitimately say "I called him a slew of racial and homophobic slurs because he was feeding". It's just not possible.

That's a hyperbole; you don't need racial or homophobic slurs to be "classified" as toxic. You don't even need to even flame at anyone. Those are extreme cases. 

Toxicity isn't as black-and-white and simple as many believe, if they just bothered to think about it at all.

> And that's why I've addressed Riot many times. I think Riot's stance is wrong. Riot are the ones enforcing this system from the Lyte days. I highly doubt the community is on board with it now. In the beginning (I mean really old, Tribunal days) the community could've been onboard, but ever since Lyte and co. took an active role by revamping the toxicity system, I really doubt they asked the community for input on every little thing.
> 
> It's probably something more like:
> Community: "there's too much toxicity in the game"
> Riot: "Ok"

The change in how the IFS responds to "KYS" says you're wrong.

>Toxicity isn't as black-and-white and simple as many believe, if they just bothered to think about it at all.

Let's try an experiment. Go to a restaurant and buy a double serving of some food you hate. Liver, Brussels sprouts, anything that makes you gag.

When you're done, I want you to describe the thought processes that went into disliking that food.

If you're being honest, you won't be able to. That's because organic emotional responses aren't planned, regardless of whether they're inherent or learned.

>That is not the objective definition of toxic. That's a general business strategy.

It's the objective definition of toxic with regard to League. Everything else is subjective.

Which is the point, really. People react to things. If someone reacts to what they perceive as feeding with profanity and/or insults, it's understandable that their targets will respond negatively in turn. In most cases, that turns out to be "I don't care for that".

League has one of the lowest capture rates for a FTP game. They have to protect their paying customers, which in turn means punishing behavior that tends to drive people away. At no point is this ever about what toxicity means to society at large.

> Let's try an experiment. Go to a restaurant and buy a double serving of some food you hate. Liver, Brussels sprouts, anything that makes you gag...

Ok, what's the moral of the story?

>It's the objective definition of toxic with regard to League. Everything else is subjective...

It needs to be connected to society. Assuming toxicity is defined objectively as anything that drives away players, then Riot needs to find what drives away players. I highly doubt retaliation does.

What drives away players in that scenario would be profanity and racial slurs and whatnot. Although I would still personally disagree with it, it would be tolerable.

But I don't think people are driven away by retaliation. Everyone retaliates, because everyone gets angry. Riot employees, you, everyone on Boards, and everyone in game. Stats are needed, but stats cannot be obtained.

People can retaliate differently, but they will retaliate. Riot placing a block on retaliation and asking people to just mute and play the game is a bad practice that only builds up negativity, which needs to be vented. 

If you see toxicity in the game, whether it be with words, inting, or trolling, are you going to absolutely stay quiet, and say or do nothing in response other than mute, report, and move on? I highly doubt that even you could do that every game.
